One method of reducing the number of distance checks is to do a form 
of sp=
ace partitioning. Break each space up into much smaller areas 
and assign e=
ach cluster to a specific area. Since you are doing this 
in 2D it would me=
an a simple check of 9 areas per area (a 3x3 matrix 
of areas, with the cur=
rent area being checked in position 5, the 
center). BTW, I haven't read th=
e entire thread so you may already 
have mentioned this...

This is used qu=
ite often in 3D games to reduce the number of objects 
being rendered and a=
lso to reduce the number of interaction checks 
needed (as in collisions).
=

> Step 2) For each genom=
e calculate its mean distance from the genomes
> in each cluster. Move the =
genome to the cluster it is closest to (if
> necessary).
> Step 3) Goto Ste=
p 2 until no more re-assignments are necessary or 
the
> number of re-assig=
nments falls below some low threshold number.

 my blog of an experimental run using points

locster.livejournal.com/43595.html

a reasonably good initial number

ring the distance between

ghtly spherical in

between any 
two

pheres'

alf

 arbitrary number which is typically used at the moment.
